definition: to guard/to protect/to defend/abbr. for 衛生|卫生, hygiene/health/abbr. for 衛生間|卫生间, toilet
surname Wei/vassal state during the Zhou Dynasty (1066-221 BC), located in present day Henan and Hebei Provinces

sentences.english: His guards shut the doors and not to listen.
sentences.chinese: 于是他把所有卫兵都遣走，关上殿门。

sentences.english: At noon, you’ll watch the changing of the guard.
sentences.chinese: 中午可以观赏到卫兵换岗的仪式。

sentences.english: Guards watch one document, only know that the ordinary people dress was president.
sentences.chinese: 卫兵一看证件，才知道这个普通着装的人竟是大总统。

sentences.english: 27So he immediately sent an executioner with orders to bring John's head. The man went, beheaded John in the prison
sentences.chinese: 随即差一个护卫兵，吩咐拿约翰的头来。

sentences.english: At the school gate stood a guard.
A guard opened the door of the train and the Commander got in.
sentences.chinese: 一个卫兵打开火车门，扎达克跨了进去。

sentences.english: Tian Taiquan accompanied us to go to the Red Army Graveyard the next day.
sentences.chinese: 第二天田太权陪我们几个去那个红卫兵墓上看看。

sentences.english: The groom walks between two rows of guardsmen.
sentences.chinese: “卫兵”们分列两行，向新郎致意。

sentences.english: Guards also sexually abused female prisoners according to the white paper.
sentences.chinese: 根据白皮书所说，监狱卫兵还对女犯人进行性侵犯。

sentences.english: The guard’s lip curled with disgust.
The Lion Guardians help herders find lost sheep, goats and cows.
sentences.chinese: 狮子卫兵帮助牧人找到丢失的羊和山羊和小牛。

sentences.english: Mao Zedong's Red Guards sometimes called themselves “new Boxers”.
sentences.chinese: 红卫兵有时自称“新义和团”。

sentences.english: Immediately, a few of his scouts came out of thestables, with horses and went out to seek Saul’s Family.
sentences.chinese: 马上，几个卫兵就骑着马去抓所罗家的人了。

sentences.english: The guard saluted the general smartly.
sentences.chinese: 卫兵非常精神地向将军行礼。

sentences.english: The boat of refugees was turned adrift by order of the guard.
sentences.chinese: 卫兵命令把难民船驱逐任其在海上漂流。

sentences.english: Guards were stationed around the prison.

definition: to guard/to protect/bodyguard (for officials in ancient times)
defense of the imperial palace or of the capital/the palace guard (or a member of that unit)
to keep goal/on duty as gatekeeper
